speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Before discussing today’s meeting, let me comment briefly on recent developments in the banking sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Conditions in that sector have broadly improved since early March, and the U.S banking system is sound and resilient.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will continue to monitor conditions in the sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to learning the right lessons from this episode and will work to prevent events like these from happening again.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As a first step in that process, last week we released Vice Chair for Supervision Barr’s Review of the Federal Reserve’s Supervision and Regulation of Silicon Valley Bank.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The review’s findings underscore the need to address our rules and supervisory practices to make for a stronger and more resilient banking system, and I am confident that we will do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: From the perspective of monetary policy, our focus remains squarely on our dual mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I understand the hardship that high inflation is causing, and we remain strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Without price stability, the economy does not work for anyone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, without price stability, we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today, the FOMC raised its policy interest rate by ¼ percentage point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since early last year, we have raised interest rates by a total of 5 percentage points in order to attain a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are also continuing to reduce our securities holdings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking ahead, we will take a data-dependent approach in determining the extent to which additional policy firming may be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will May 3, 2023 have more to say about today’s monetary policy actions after briefly reviewing economic Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The U.S. economy slowed significantly last year, with real GDP rising at a below-trend pace of 0.9 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The pace of economic growth in the first quarter of this year continued to be modest, at 1.1 percent, despite a pickup in consumer spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Activity in the housing sector remains weak, largely reflecting higher mortgage, mortgage rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Higher interest rates and slower output growth also appear to be weighing on business fixed investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market remains very tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the first three months of the year, job gains averaged 345,000 jobs per month.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate remained very low in March, at 3.5 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even so, there are some signs that supply and demand in the labor market are coming back into better balance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor force participation rate has moved up in recent months, particularly for individuals aged 25 to 54 years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nominal wage growth has sown—shown some signs of easing, and job vacancies have declined so far this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But overall, labor demand still substantially exceeds the supply of available workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation remains well above our longer-run goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the 12 months ending in March, total PCE prices rose 4.2 percent; excluding the volatile food and energy categories, core PCE prices rose 4.6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has moderated somewhat since the middle of last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, inflation pressures continue to run high, and the process of getting inflation back down to 2 percent has a long way to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Despite elevated inflation, longer-term inflation expectations appear to remain well anchored, as reflected in a broad range of surveys of households, businesses, and forecasters, as well as measures from financial markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s monetary policy actions are guided by, by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are acutely aware May 3, 2023 that high inflation imposes significant hardship, as it erodes purchasing power, especially for Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are highly attentive to the risks that high inflation pose—poses to both sides of our mandate, and we are strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At today’s meeting, the Committee raised the target range for the federal funds rate by ¼ percentage point, bringing the target range to 5 to 5¼ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re continuing to [carry out] the process of significantly reducing our securities holdings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With today’s action, we have raised interest rates by 5 percentage points in a little more than a year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are seeing the effects of our policy tightening on demand in the most interest rate–sensitive sectors of the economy, particularly housing and investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will take time, however, for the full effects of monetary restraint to be realized, especially on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, the economy is likely to face further headwinds from tighter credit conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Credit conditions had already been tightening over the past year or so in response to our policy actions and a softer economic outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the strains that emerged in the banking sector in early March appear to be resulting in even tighter credit conditions for households and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In turn, these tighter credit conditions are likely to weigh on economic activity, hiring, and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The extent of these effects remains uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In light of these uncertain headwinds, along with the monetary policy restraint we have put in place, our future policy actions will depend on how events unfold.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In determining the extent to which additional policy firming may be appropriate to return inflation to 2 percent over time, the Committee will take into account the cumulative tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and inflation, and economic and financial developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we will make that determination meeting by meeting, based on the totality of May 3, 2023 incoming data and their implications for the outlook for economic activity and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL are prepared to do more if greater monetary policy restraint is warranted.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We remain committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal and to keep longer-term inflation expectations well anchored.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Reducing inflation is likely to require a period of below-trend growth and some softening of labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Restoring price stability is essential to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices over the longer run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude: We understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Fed will do everything we can to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, taking your question—of course, today our decision was to raise the federal funds rate by 25 basis points.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A, a decision on a pause was not made today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You will have noticed that in the—in the statement from March, we had a sentence that said the Committee anticipates that some additional policy firming may be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That sentence is, is not in, in the statement anymore.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We took that out, and instead we’re saying that, in May 3, 2023 determining the extent to which additional policy firming may be appropriate to return inflation Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL to 2 percent over time, the Committee will take into account certain factors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we—that’s a—that’s a meaningful change that we’re no longer saying that we anticipate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we’ll be driven by incoming data meeting by meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’ll approach that question at the June meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the—the staff’s forecast is—so let me say—start by saying that that’s not my own most likely case, which is really that, that the economy will continue to grow at, at a modest rate this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think that’s—so different people on the Committee have different forecasts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s, that’s my own assessment of the most likely path.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: [The] staff produces its own forecast, and it’s independent of the forecasts of, of the participants, which include the Governors and the Reserve Bank presidents, of course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think this is a healthy thing—that the, the staff is writing down what they really think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re not especially influenced by what the Governors think, and vice versa.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Governors are not taking what the staff says and just writing that down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s actually good that the, the staff and individual participants can have different perspectives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, broadly, the forecast was for a mild recession, and by that I would characterize as one in which the rise in unemployment is smaller than is—has been typical in modern-era recessions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t want to characterize the staff’s forecast for this meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll, we’ll leave that to the minutes—but broadly, broadly similar to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I wouldn’t want to speculate specifically, but I will say this: These are fiscal policy matters, for starters, and they’re, they’re for Congress and the Administration—for the elected parts of the government to deal with.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they’re really consigned to them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: From our standpoint, I would just say this: It’s essential that the debt ceiling be raised in a timely way, so that the U.S. government can pay all of its bills when they’re due.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A failure to do that would be unprecedented.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’d be in uncharted territory, and the—and the consequences to the U.S. economy would be highly uncertain and could, could be quite a[d]verse.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’ll just leave it there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we don’t give advice to either side.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We just would point out that it—that it’s very important that this be done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the, the other point I’ll make about that, though, is that no one should assume that the Fed can protect the economy from the potential, you know, short- and long-term effects of a failure to pay our bills on time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we—it’s, it would be so uncertain that it’s just as important that, that this—we never get to a place where we’re actually talking about or even having a situation where the U.S. government’s not paying its bills.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t say that it did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was—of course, it’s something that came up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We talk a lot about risks to the—to the outlook, and that will—that come up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A number of people did raise that as a risk to the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t say that it was important in today’s monetary policy decision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the February 14 presentation—I didn’t remember it very well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But now, of course, I’ve gone back and looked at it very carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I did remember it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And what it was was a general presentation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was an informational briefing of the whole Board—the entire Board.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think all members were there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it was about interest rate risk in the banks and, and lots of data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there was one page on Silicon Valley Bank, which talked about, you know, the amount of losses they—or mark-to-market losses they had in their portfolio.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There was nothing in it about—that I recall, anyway, about, about the risk of a bank run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it was—I think the takeaway was, they were going away to do a—an assessment, a vertical—sorry, horizontal assessment of, of banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It wasn’t—it, it wasn’t presented as an urgent or alarming situation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was presented as a—as an informational, nondecisional kind of a thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I thought it was a good presentation and, and, as I said, did remember it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of what we’re doing—of course, I think banks themselves are, are—many, many banks are now, are attending to liquidity and taking opportunity now, really, since, since the events of, of early March, to build liquidity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you asked about the separation principle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I—you know, like so many things, it, it’s very useful.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, ultimately, it has its limits.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I, I think in this particular case, we have found that the monetary policy tools and the financial stability tools are not in conflict.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re both—they’re working well together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve used our, our financial stability tools to support banks through our lending facilities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, at the May 3, 2023 same time, we’ve been able to use our monetary policy tools to foster maximum employment Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I mean, I didn’t say it wasn’t alarming.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was—they’re pointing out something that they’re working on and that they’re on the case—that, that, you know, that—I’m not sure whether they mentioned—I think they did, actually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They mentioned that they had taken regulatory action matter—or supervisory action in the form of matters requiring attention.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that was also in the presentation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it was to say: Yes, this is a bank, and there are many other banks that are experiencing this—these things, and we’re on the case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, you know, we certainly don’t—and I don’t have an agenda to further consolidate banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s been—consolidation has been a factor in the U.S. banking industry really since interstate banking and before that even—it goes back more than 30 years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You—when I was in the government a while back, I think there were 14,000 banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now there May 3, 2023 are 4,000 and change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s going on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I personally have long felt that having small-, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL medium-, and large-size banks is a, a great part of our banking system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the community banks serve particular customers very well; regional banks serve very important purposes, and the various kinds of G-SIBs do as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think it’s healthy to have a, you know, an arrange—a range of different kinds of banks doing different things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that’s a positive thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Is it a financial—so I would just say, in terms of J.P. Morgan buying First Republic, the FDIC really runs the process of closing and selling a closed bank completely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That, that is their role, so I really don’t have a comment on, on that process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As you know, there’s an exception to the deposit cap for a failing bank.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it was legitimate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think the FDIC, I believe, is bound by law to take the bid that is the least-cost bid.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would assume that’s what they did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I think it’s probably good policy that we, we don’t want the largest banks doing big acquisitions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is the policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And—but this is—this is an exception for a failing bank.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I, I think it’s actually a good outcome for the banking system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It also would have—would have been a good—a good outcome for the banking system had one of the regional banks bought, bought this company.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that could have been the outcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, ultimately, we have to follow the law in our agencies, and the law is, it goes to the, the least-cost bid.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think—I think I follow that up by saying, it’s, it’s quite impossible to have a precise estimate of the words to that effect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, in principle, that’s the idea.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, when we—we’ve been raising interest rates, and that raises the price of credit, and that, in a sense, restricts credit in the economy, working through the price mechanism.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, when banks raise their credit standards, that can also make credit tighter in a kind of broadly similar way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It isn’t—it isn’t possible to make a kind of clean translation between one and the other, although firms are trying that and, you know, we’re trying it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, ultimately, we have to be—we have to be honest and humble about our ability to make a precise assessment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it does complicate the task of achieving, you know, a sufficiently restrictive stance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think, conceptually, though, we think that, you know, interest rates—in principle, we won’t have to raise the rates quite as high as we would have had this not happened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The extent of that is so hard to predict because we don’t know how persistent these, these effects will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t know how large they’ll be and how long they’ll take to be transmitted.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s, that’s what we’ll be watching carefully to find out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s that—this is just something that we have to factor in as we—as we want to find ourselves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess I would say it this way: The assessment of, of the extent to which additional policy firming may be appropriate is going to be an ongoing one, meeting by meeting, and we’re going to be looking at the factors that I mentioned that—they’re listed in, in May 3, 2023 the statement, the obvious factors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s, that’s the way we’re going to be thinking about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL And that’s really all we can do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I say, it does complicate—we, we have, you know, a broad understanding of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Credit tightening is a different thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a lot of literature on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But translating it into, into rate hikes is uncertain, let’s say—it adds even further uncertainty.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, we’ll be able to see what’s happening with credit conditions—what’s happening with lending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We get—there’s a lot of data on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’ll, we’ll factor that into our decisionmaking.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s going to be an ongoing assessment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to need data to accumulate on that—not an assessment that we’ve made, as—that, that would mean we think we’ve reached that point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I just think it’s, it’s not possible to say that with confidence now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, nonetheless, you, you will know that the Summary of Economic Projections from the March meeting showed that in—at that point in time, that the median participant thought that this was—this was the appropriate level of the—of the ultimate high level of rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll revisit that at the June meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s—you know, we’re just going to have to—before we really declare that, I think we’re going to have to see data accumulating and, and, you know, make that—as I mentioned, it’s an ongoing assessment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re going to release the results of this SLOOS on May 8, in line with our usual time frame.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would just say that the SLOOS is broadly consistent, when you see it, with how we and others have been thinking about the situation and what we’re seeing from other sources.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You will have seen the Beige Book and listened to the various earnings calls that indicate that midsize banks have—some of them had been tightening their lending standards.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Banking data will show that lending has continued to grow, but the pace has been slowing really since the second half of last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, we—the reason is that we—again, with our monetary policy we’re try—trying to reach and then—and then stay at a, for an extended period, a level of policy—a policy stance that’s sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, that’s what we’re trying to do with our—with our tool.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think slowing down was the right move.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I think it’s enabled us to see more data, and it will continue to do May 3, 2023 so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I—you know, we really—you know, we have to balance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We always have to balance Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the risk of not doing enough and, and not getting inflation under control against the risk of maybe slowing down economic activity too much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we thought that this rate hike, along with the meaningful change in, in our policy statement, was the right way to balance that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, as I mentioned, I would just say that this assessment will be an ongoing one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You—you know, you can’t—with, with economic data, you, you can’t—you’ve, you’ve seen—take inflation for a minute.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Look, look back.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve seen inflation come down—move back up two or three times since March of 2021.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve seen inflation have a few months of coming down and then come right back up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think you’re going to want to see that—you know, that a few months of data will, will persuade you that you’ve—that you’ve got this right, kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we, we have the luxury: We’ve raised 500 basis points.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that policy is tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think real rates are probably—that you can calculate them many different ways.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But one way is to look at the nominal rate and then subtract a, a reasonable estimate of, of, let’s say, one-year inflation, which might be 3 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’ve got 2 percent real rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s meaningfully above what most people would—many people, anyway, would, would assess as, you know, the neutral rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So policy is tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you see that in interest—interest-sensitive activities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you also begin to see it more and more in, in other activities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if you—if you put the—you put the credit tightening on top of that and the QT that’s, that’s May 3, 2023 ongoing, I think, I think you feel like, you know, we’re, we may not be far off—we’re possibly Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL even at—that level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Look—I think we’re always going to have 2 percent as our, our target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re always going to be focusing on getting there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s—let me just say, that’s not what we’re looking for.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re looking for inflation going down to 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, we—that’s, that’s not a question that’s in front of us, and it would depend on so many other things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, ultimately, we’re not looking to get to 3 percent and then drop our tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have a, a goal of getting to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think it’s going to take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t think it’ll be a smooth process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, I think we’re going to—we’re going to need to stay at this for a while.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think they, they—you know, they, they will both matter equally at that point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right now, you have a labor market that’s still extraordinarily tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You still got 1.6 job openings, even with the lower job openings number, for every unemployed person.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do see some evidence of softening in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, overall, you’re near a 50-year low in unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Wages—you all will have seen that the wage number from late May 3, 2023 last week, and it’s—whenever it was.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, it’s, it’s a couple of percentage points Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL above what would be—what would be consistent with 2 percent inflation over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we do see some softening; we see new labor supply coming in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These are very positive developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the labor market is very, very strong, whereas inflation is, you know, running high—well above our—well above our goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And right now, we need to be focusing on bringing inflation down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Fortunately, we’ve been able to do that so far without unemployment going up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think—you know, I know what’s printed in the Summary of Economic Projections and all that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think you can deduce exactly what you said about what participants think, because you don’t know what they were thinking for first-quarter GDP at that point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They could have been thinking about a fairly low number.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Anyway, in any case, I’ll just say, I, I continue to think that it’s possible that this time is really different.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the reason is, there’s just so much excess demand, really, in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s interesting, as, you know, we’ve raised rates by 5 percentage points in 14 months, and the unemployment rate is 3½ percent, pretty much where it was—even lower than where it was when we started.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So job openings are still very, very high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see—by surveys and much, May 3, 2023 much [other] evidence—that, that conditions are cooling gradually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s—it really is Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL different.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it wasn’t supposed to be possible for job openings to decline by as much of the—as they’ve declined without unemployment going up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, that’s what we’ve seen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we—there are no promises in this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it just seems that, to me, that it’s possible that we can continue to have a cooling in the labor market without having the big increases in unemployment that have gone with many, you know, prior episodes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, that would be against history.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I fully appreciate that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That would be against the, the pattern.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I do think that it—that this, that the situation in the labor market, with so much excess demand, yet, you know, wages are actually—wages have been moving down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Wage increases have been moving down, and that’s a good sign—down to a more sustainable level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that—I think it’s still possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I—you know, I think, you know, the, the case of, of avoiding a recession is, in my view, more likely than that of having, having a recession.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s not—it’s not that the case of having a recession is—I don’t rule that out, either.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s possible that we will have what I hope would be a mild recession.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we look at a range of wage, wage measures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then that’s in nominal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then—so you assume wages should be equal to productivity increases plus inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so you can—you can look at, you know, the employment compensation index, average hourly earnings, the Atlanta wage tracker, compensation per hour—basically, those four and many others.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you can—you can look at, at what the—what they would have to run at over a long period of time for that to be consistent with 2 percent inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They can May 3, 2023 deviate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, corporate margins can go up and down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there is a feature of long Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL expansions where they do go down—where labor gets a bigger share toward later, later in a recession—sorry, later in an expansion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, yeah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The, the—you know, and we calculate those, and you have to take the precision with a degree of—a degree of salt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would say that what they will show is that, you know, if, if the—if wages are running at 5 percent, 3 percent is closer to where they need to be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Wage increases and closer to 3 percent, roughly, is what it would take to get—to be consistent with inflation over a longer period of time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I—by the way, I don’t want to—I do not think that wages are the principal driver of inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re asking me a very specific question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think there are many things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think wages and prices tend to move together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s very hard to say what’s causing what.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, I’ve never said that, you know, that—that wages are really the principal driver, because I don’t think that’s really right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So higher profits and higher margins are what happens when you have an imbalance between supply and demand: too much demand, not enough supply.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve been in a situation in many parts of the economy where, where supply has been fixed or, or not flexible enough.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so, you know, the way the market clears is through higher prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So to get, I, I think—as goods pipelines have, have gotten, you know, back to normal so that we May 3, 2023 don’t have the long waits and the shortages and that kind of thing—I think you will see inflation Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL come down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’ll see—you’ll see corporate margins coming down as a result of return of full competition, where there’s enough supply to meet demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then it’s—then it’s, then you’re really back to full competition.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s—that would be the dynamic I would expect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I didn’t catch the last part.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Oh, yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sorry, sorry, sorry.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay, I got it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, we look at a combination of data and, and forecasts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, the whole idea is to—is to create a good forecast based on what you see in the data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re always, always looking at both.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, and it will—of course, it’ll be the obvious things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll be readings on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll be readings on wages, on economic growth, on the labor market, and all of those many things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, so we can begin to assess how that fits in with monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’ll, that’ll be an important thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I just—you know, we’ll be looking at everything.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s— May 3, 2023 again, I would just point out, we’ve raised rates by 5 percentage points.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are shrinking the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And now we have credit conditions tightening—not just in the normal way, but perhaps a little bit more, due to what’s happened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we have to factor all of that in and, and make our assessment of—you know, of whether our policy stance is sufficiently restrictive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we have to do that in a world where policy works with long and variable lags.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is challenging.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, we, we will make our best assessment, and that’s what we think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we on the Committee have a—have a view that inflation is going to come down—not so quickly, but it’ll take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And in that world, if that forecast is broadly right, it would not be appropriate and—to cut rates, and we won’t cut rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you have a different forecast and, you know, markets—or have been, from time to time, pricing in, you know, quite rapid reductions in inflation, you know, we’d, we’d factor that in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s not our forecast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, the history of the last two years has been very much that inflation moves down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Particularly now, if you look at nonhousing services, it really, really hasn’t moved much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s quite stable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, so we think we’ll have to—demand will have to weaken a little bit, and labor market conditions, conditions may have to soften a bit more to begin to see progress there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, in that world, it wouldn’t be—it wouldn’t be appropriate for us to cut rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we looked at that very carefully, as you would imagine.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, the—it’s, it’s really not contributing, we don’t think, now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It hasn’t actually been growing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it moved up—moved down and then moved back up to where it was.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What happened in the—when, when there were the big deposit flows, which, by the way, have really stabilized now—what happened was, institutional investors took their uninsured deposits and put them in government money market funds, which bought paper from the Federal Home Loan Banks and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the course of, of maybe the last year, retail investors had been gradual—as they do in every tightening cycle, they’ve been gradually moving their deposits into higher-yielding places such as CDs and, and other things, including money market funds.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s a gradual process that is quite natural and happens during a, a tightening cycle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What was unusual, really, was the institutional investors moving their uninsured deposits and spreading them around and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it doesn’t seem to have had any—any effect overall on the overnight repo facility.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is really there to, to help us keep rates where they’re supposed to be, and it’s, it’s serving that purpose very well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would just say, it’s —I, I don’t really think we should be—we shouldn’t even be talking about a world in which the U.S. doesn’t pay its bills.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It just—it just May 3, 2023 shouldn’t be a thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and again, I would just say, we don’t—no one should assume that the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL Fed can do—can really protect the economy and the financial system and our reputation globally from, from the damage that such, such an event might inflict.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I didn’t—I didn’t take part in creating the report or doing the work, but I do—I have read it, of course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I find it persuasive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I would say it this way: A, a very large—a large bank, not a very large bank—a large bank failed quite suddenly and unexpectedly in a way that threatened to spread contagion into the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the only thing that, that I’m really focused on is to understand what went wrong, what happened, and, and identify what we need to do to address that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Some of that is—may, it may just have been technology evolving.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we have to keep up with all that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But some of it may be our policies, and—supervisory and regulatory, whatever.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What our job is now is, identify those things and implement them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s kind of the only thing I care about is—and I think—I feel like I am accountable for doing everything I can to make sure that that happens.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess I would—I guess I would say it this way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There were three large banks, really, from the very beginning that were at the heart of the stress that we—that we saw in early March, the severe period of stress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those have now all been resolved, and all the depositors have been protected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that the resolution and sale of, of First Republic kind of draws a line under that period of—is an important step toward drawing a line under that period of, of severe stress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I also think we are very focused on what’s happening with credit availability, particularly, you know, with what you saw in the—in the Beige Book, and you will see in the SLOOS, is, is small and medium—medium-sized, small and medium-sized banks who are feeling that they need to tighten credit standards—build liquidity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: More broadly, we, we will continue to very carefully monitor what’s going on in the banking system, and we’ll factor that assessment into our decisions in an important way, going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me say, first of all, I’ve been Chair of the Board for five-plus years now, and I fully recognize that we made mistakes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’ve learned some May 3, 2023 new things as well, and we need to do better.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, as I mentioned, I thought the report was Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL unflinching and appropriately so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I welcome it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I agree with and will support those recommendations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I do feel that I’m personally accountable to do what I can to foster measures that will address the problems.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on, on the Vice Chair for Supervision, you know, the place to start is, is the statutory role, which is quite unusual.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Vice Chair, it says, shall deploy policy recommendations—“develop policy recommendations for the Board regarding supervision and regulation of depository institution .

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: companies .

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: , and shall oversee the supervision and regulation of such firms.” So this is Congress establishing a four-year term for someone else on the Board—not, not the Chair—as Vice Chair for Supervision who really gets to set the agenda for supervision and regulation for the Board of Governors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Congress wanted that person to be—to have political accountability for developing that agenda.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the way it works—the way it has worked in practice for me is, I’ve had a good working relationship.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I give my, my counsel, my input privately, and that’s—I offer that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I have good conversations, and I try to contribute constructively.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I respect the authority that Congress has deferred on that person, including working with, with Vice Chair Barr and, and his predecessor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think that’s the way it’s supposed to work, and that’s appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I believe that’s what the law requires.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know—but, but it isn’t—I wouldn’t say it’s a matter of complete deference.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s more, I have a—I have a role in, in presenting my views and discussing—having an intelligent discussion about what’s going on and why.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, that’s, that’s my input.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, ultimately, that person does get to set the agenda and gets to take things to the Board of Governors and really, in supervision, has sole authority over supervision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve had a few, sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, honestly, you don’t—you don’t get to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, my focus is on what—control the controllable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As one of my great mentors used to always say, “Control the controllable.” What we control now is, make a fair assessment, learn the right lessons, figure out what the fixes are, and implement them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and I think that, that Vice Chair Barr’s report is an excellent first step in that, but we’ve got to follow through.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So support for the 25 basis point rate increase was very strong across the board.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say there are a number of people—and, you know, you’ll see this in the minutes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t want to try to do the head count in real time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But people did talk about pausing, but not so much at this meeting, you know, that we’re—I mean, there’s a sense that we’re, we’re—that, you know, we’re much closer to the end of this than to the beginning, that—you know, as I mentioned, if you—if you add up all the tightening that’s going on through various channels, it’s—we, we feel like we—you know, we’re getting close or, or maybe even there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that, again, that’s going to be an ongoing assessment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and we’re going to be looking at those factors that we listed and—to determine whether there’s, there’s more to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t want to—I couldn’t—I couldn’t really say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I just think we’re—I think we—look, I think we’ve moved a long way fairly quickly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we can afford to look at the data and, and make a careful assessment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I just would start with something that’s changed, really, which is this—the run on Silicon Valley Bank was out of keeping with the speed of runs through history.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that now needs to be reflected in some—in some way in regulation and in supervision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It—we know—now that we know it’s possible, I think we didn’t—no one thought that was possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No one—I’m not aware of anybody thinking that this could happen so—quite so quickly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that, you know, that will play through.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I, you know—it will be up to Vice Chair Barr to really take the lead in designing the ways to address that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think—I think that’s one thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I guess I would just say that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Then, you know—that we’re going to—obviously, we’re going to revisit [this].

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s pretty clear we need—to me, anyways—clear that we need to strengthen both supervision and regulations for banks of this size.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’m, I’m thinking that we’re on the—on track to do that as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s—see, that’s, that’s what Vice Chair Barr’s role really is, and he’ll take the lead on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.
